From the Boston Public Library site:

"The Boston Public Library offers free tours of the Boston Public Library exhibition Torn in Two: The 150th Anniversary of the Civil War which includes 50 historic maps interwoven with 40 photographs, paintings, prints, diaries, political cartoons, music and press of the period, all from the Boston Public Library's special collections. The tours last about an hour and will include the companion exhibition, Home Front: Boston and the Civil War. They are led by volunteers and begin at the Dartmouth Street entrance of the Central Library in Copley Square. No appointment is necessary".

Where to Meet:

T.J. Maher will be at the Dartmouth Street entrance starting at 5:45 pm. Tours run from 6:00 pm to 7:00 pm. Let's grab a tour, see what is there, then grab a bite to eat after the tour!

T.J. is five foot seven, with short brown hair, blue eyes, a "Hello My Name is T.J." nametag, and a red MEETUP sign attached to his black messenger bag.

About the exhibit Torn in Two: 150th Anniversary of the Civil War:

http://maps.bpl.org/events/

"The American Civil War is one of the defining events in American history. To commemorate its 150th anniversary, the Norman B. Leventhal Map Center at the Boston Public Library will present the exhibition, Torn in Two: 150th Anniversary of the Civil War. This multimedia display takes a geographic and cartographic approach to exploring and illuminating the causes of the conflict, the conduct of the war and how the war was remembered in later years. It will showcase 50 historic maps interwoven with 40 photographs, paintings, prints, diaries, political cartoons, music and press of the period, all from the Boston Public Library's special collections.

"The exhibition will be divided into three major temporal sections. The initial section, 'Rising Tensions,' will exmaine the economic, social, and political differences between North and South that led to war. 'Nation in Conflict,' will focus on the war itself - the strategies and how it was conducted as well as how those at home followed the war's progress and contributed to the war effort. And the final section, 'Remembering Battles and Heroes,' will document the nation's attempts to commemorate the battles and honor the lives that were lost during the war.

"The exhibition will be on display from May through December 2011. The Library and the Map Center will also sponsor extensive educational outreach programs including guided tours, Lowell Lecture Series presentations, family events, a fully illustrated catalog, educational programs for grades K to 12, and interactive elements - computer stations with touch screen activities, scavenger hunts, and identity cards. A virtual exhibition will be featured permanently on the Map Center's website".

The "Torn in Two" virtual exhibit website: http://tornintwo.org/

Directions:

http://www.bpl.org/general/hours.htm

"By subway
Green Line to Copley Station.

Orange Line to Back Bay/South End Station. Walk down Dartmouth Street to Copley Square.

"By car
"Interstate 93 (from north or south) Take Storrow Drive exit. Take Copley Square exit off of Storrow Drive. The exit deadends at a signal light. The cross street is Beacon. Take a right on Beacon Street. While on Beacon Street, you will cross Berkeley, Clarendon, and Dartmouth Streets. The next street is Exeter. Take a left onto Exeter (it is a one-way street). While on Exeter, you will cross Marlborough Street, Commonwealth Avenue, and Newbury Street. The next cross street is Boylston. The Library is on the corner of Exeter and Boylston Streets."
